affiliation.orgName: Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Medicine

analytic.title: Cogstim: Practical Model, Page 1 Cogstim: A Shared Decision-Making Model to Support Older Adults' Brain Health

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: The lack of effective treatments for cognitive decline in older adults has led to interest in the possibility that lifestyle interventions can help to prevent changes in mental functioning and reduce risk for dementia. Multiple lifestyle factors have been related to risk for decline, and multicomponent intervention studies suggest that changing older adults' behaviors can have a positive impact on their cognition. How to translate these findings into a practical model for clinical use with older adults, however, is not clear. In this Forum, we propose a shared decision-making model to support clinicians' efforts to promote brain health in older persons. The model organizes risk and protective factors into three broad groups based on their mechanism of action and provides older persons basic information to allow them to make evidence-and preference-based choices in choosing goals for effective brain health programs. A final component includes basic instruction in behavior change strategies such as goal setting, self-monitoring, and problem solving. The implementation of the model will support older persons' efforts to develop a personally relevant and effective brain healthy lifestyle that may help to reduce their risk for cognitive decline.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Despite extensive efforts, attempts to develop pharmacologic treatments to prevent cognitive decline and dementia in older adults have largely been unsuccessful, and until recently, no new treatments for Alzheimer's disease had been approved in the US for nearly two decades. Given the predicted increase in Alzheimer's disease and other dementias over the next 20 years [1], the development of effective strategies to prevent cognitive decline is clearly important to older persons, caregivers, clinicians, and society [2].

div.head: Alzheimer's disease and cognitive decline are related to lifestyle
div.p: With the continuing failure of pharmacologic interventions and mounting evidence that lifestyle factors are associated with risk for cognitive decline, interest has increased in how changes in lifestyle factors such as exercise, diet, meditation, cognitive training, and sleep may reduce risk for cognitive decline in older adults [3,4]. Several reviews have documented the role that lifestyle may play in developing cognitive problems and have pointed to the potential impact of lifestyle changes on risk [3][4][5]. These observations have led to the idea that systematic efforts to help older adults maintain and improve their brain health-engage in "brain maintenance" [6] -may be key in reducing cognitive decline in older adults, while perhaps also reducing their risk for developing Alzheimer's disease and other dementias.

div.head: Older people are concerned, but may not know what to do
div.p: Research shows that older adults are interested in the idea of brain health and are willing to make lifestyle changes to help maintain it, but do not know what they Cogstim: Practical Model, Page 4 should do or how to do it. One survey [7] showed that about 30% of persons 40 years and older are worried that they have already experienced cognitive decline and almost half believe that they will develop dementia, even though their actual risk is much lower.

Another study showed that almost half of persons aged 50 to 64 believed they were likely to develop dementia, but only 5.2% of them had discussed dementia prevention with their physician [8]. Another study showed that older individuals were unsure how to prevent cognitive decline [9], and those who knew how to approach the problem were likely to cite a single strategy rather than correctly noting the benefits of addressing several factors [9].
Many older persons endorse a strong belief in heredity as a determining factor in cognitive decline and believe that a family history of dementia makes it inevitable [7].

The fatalistic view that risk for dementia is strongly determined by heredity is in marked contrast to research that show that less than half of the observed risk for cognitive decline and dementia can be attributed to neuropathology [10,11]. Authors have referred to factors associated with preserved cognition in the face of significant neuropathology as "resilience factors," [11]. While not all are easily addressed through lifestyle modification, some, such as diet, exercise, meditation, and cognitive training, can readily be incorporated into older adults' lives.

div.head: Plethora of risk and protective factors
div.p: Research shows that numerous factors are associated with risk for cognitive decline in older persons [3] but no consensus exists on which should be targeted. For example, the report of the US National Academy concluded that efforts to prevent Cogstim: Practical Model, Page 5 cognitive decline and dementia should focus on three areas [12], the Lancet Commission report [3] discusses 17 factors, while a review by Yu et al. found evidence for as many as 28 [13]. Further, a number of factors are less well established but may be modified through behavioral interventions, such as social engagement [14], and sense of purpose in life [15]. The amount of conflicting information available online, in academic publications, and popular books thus may make it difficult for older adults and the clinicians with whom they work to make informed decisions about lifestyle changes to promote brain health. A strategy to organize the disparate types of information to support older adults' efforts to develop brain healthy lifestyles would be useful.

div.head: Shared decision-making model
div.p: In this Forum, we argue that implementing a shared decision-making model will allow gerontologists to help older adults develop brain health lifestyles. The model presented here provides a framework to help older adults develop rational, realistic, and effective goals for behavior change that will support their brain health and potentially reduce their risk for cognitive decline. The shared decision-making model presented here integrates psychoeducation on risk and protective factors for cognitive decline and dementia, provides guidance on evidence-based judgments on goal choice and includes implementation of behavior change strategies to support older adults and those who work with them in developing more brain healthy lifestyles.

div.head: The model
div.p: The model comprises three elements ( Table 1) changes in neurohumoral signaling. Aerobic exercise thus has multiple effects on the body that may promote brain health; it can affect biochemical signaling through its impact on a number of substances, including brain-derived neurotrophic growth factor [21], vascular endothelial growth factor [22], insulin-like growth factor [22], and irisin [23]. Several other activities related to brain health may also share this mechanism [24][25][26]. We thus argue that it is reasonable to hypothesize a second mechanism underlying brain health activities that is distinct from cognitive activity itself when various behaviors act through neurohumoral factors to improve brain function.

div.head: Reducing neuroinflammation
div.p: A third key mechanism underlying lifestyle changes to support brain health is the reduction of inflammation. Substantial research suggests that peripheral inflammation may play a role in cognitive decline with increasing age [27,28]. For example, systemic levels of interleukin-6 (IL6) have been associated with global changes in cognition over time [29] and Lin et al [30] showed that levels of IL6 mediated performance on a measure of processing speed.

Diet has consistently been associated with risk for cognitive decline and of developing dementia [31,32]. The Mediterranean diet, for example, is associated with reduced levels of systemic markers of inflammation [33]. Although the reasons for the association of diets such as the Mediterranean and MIND diet with reduced risk for cognitive decline and dementia [32,34,35] have not been definitively established, current explanations focus on the diets' content of polyphenols and antioxidants [36].

div.head: Evidence-based criteria for activity choice
div.p: Cogstim: Practical Model, Page 9

The shared decision-making model implementation presented here suggests that older adults' choice of brain health activities should be guided by evidence-based criteria [37]: (1) consistency of research results across multiple studies, as evidenced by several good quality studies or meta-analyses; (2) effect size ("bang for the buck"), in this case noting the important difference between a factor associated with statistical significance and one associated with a large and clinically relevant effect size (e.g., some meta-analyses have shown that a diet high in fruit and vegetables is associated with a 40-50% lower risk for cognitive decline and dementia); and (3) factors that may have an impact on multiple mechanisms ("twofers"), such as aerobic exercise or meditation which may stimulate the brain while at the same time reducing inflammation [36,38]. Psychoeducation in the model therefore aims to give older persons basic tools for understanding and evaluating clinical studies. Research shows that one of the most common uses of the internet by older adults is to search for health information [39].
Older adults find a great deal of information, but may not be able to evaluate it [40,41].

They thus should be helped to understand issues such as the distinction between statistical significance and clinical importance [42], the rigor of various clinical research designs [43], and the importance of study replication [44] in guiding their choices about lifestyle interventions. The criteria and how they are assessed are listed in Table 3. preferences into account. The model emphasizes early instruction in SMART goal setting [50]. This acronym is based on the idea that goals should be specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART).

3) Behavior change strategies. Assisting older adults with behavior change, even something as seemingly simple as regularly taking medications, can be challenging for practitioners. Research, however, shows that clinicians can help patients change health-related behaviors [51], but it is essential that they are provided with concrete instruction and support for behavior change.

div.head: Summary
div.p: In this Forum, we have suggested that clinicians can help older adults develop more brain healthy lifestyles. We argue that it may be useful to organize potential behavior change approaches to help them develop more brain healthy lifestyles in a structured model that provides guidance in activity selection while allowing for individual preferences. While implementing the model in busy clinical practice may be challenging, the need for a systematic effort to reduce cognitive decline and dementia incidence in older adults is clear. The personal and societal cost of not addressing this issue is likely to be great, but with psychoeducation and support for behavior change, it may be Tables/Figures Table 1

div.head: Consistent findings
div.p: Multiple positive studies weighted toward studies with higher quality, larger sample sizes, meta-analyses

div.head: Effect size
div.p: Effect size found in representative studies, especially in meta-analyses or controlled trials ("bang for the buck")

div.head: Multiple mechanisms
div.p: Judgment that the intervention may affect multiple mechanisms related to brain health ("twofer")

figure.figDesc: . The first element of the model is the organization of the large number of possible lifestyle interventions related to brain health into three broad categories representing hypothesized mechanisms by which Cogstim: Practical Model, Page 6 they affect brain health. This organization simplifies and facilitates psychoeducational efforts and helps older adults understand how to make informed choices about lifestyle changes. The second element is helping older adults develop an understanding of evidence-based health principles to give them essential information to make lifestyle choices that are most likely to be effective while being consistent with their interests and lifestyle. Finally, the third element is providing older adults with basic support for behavior change, including assistance in goal setting, self-monitoring, and problem solving. We refer to the model with the term "Cogstim" based on the hypothesized three key elements of brain health interventions, cognitive activity with brain stimulation while reducing inflammation. __________________________________ Insert Table 1 about here __________________________________ Mechanisms of activities promoting brain health The first element of the Cogstim model is based on the hypothesis that although many things have been associated with risk for and protection from cognitive decline and dementia, they can be conveniently grouped as involving three basic mechanisms by which they affect brain health. This simplifies and helps organize the large number of possible behavior change targets. When integrated with the evidence-based guidelines discussed below, this organization can better help older adults make informed choices about lifestyle changes. These three mechanisms include preserving cognitive reserve, stimulating the brain through neurohumoral activity, and decreasing inflammation through diet, exercise, improved sleep, and stress management. Cogstim: Practical Model, Page 7 __________________________________ Insert Table 2 about here __________________________________ Cognitive activity In this section, cognitive activity is broadly defined to mean using mental functions in a goal directed way (e.g., reading, taking classes, or working puzzles) that is likely to maintain and improve older adults' cognitive function and enhance their level of cognitive reserve. This definition includes not only formal computer-based cognitive training but also mentally stimulating activities such as reading, solving puzzles, using a computer, or engaging in social activities. Substantial evidence supports the utility of ongoing use of mental abilities as strategy for preserving cognitive function with increasing age. Cognitive reserve [16],while often thought of as an accumulation of cognitive experiences over the lifespan, is also related to cognitive and social activities in later life[17,18]. Number and frequency of mentally stimulating activities were related to lower incidence of mild cognitive impairment[19]. Computer-based cognitive training has been related to reduced risk for dementia[20].Brain stimulationA second general mechanism by which activities can have a positive impact on brain health is by way of brain stimulation. By this, we mean that various activities, especially aerobic exercise, have been shown to have positive effects on neural cell growth, arborization and synaptogenesis, perhaps because of and often related Cogstim: Practical Model, Page 8

The structure provided by the organization of the mechanisms and guidance on selecting activities based on evidence-based criteria can then be implemented in a shared decision-making (SDM) approach during clinical care. Although definitions of SDM vary[45] our implementation views the clinician as an expert consultant who provides psychoeducation, guidance on goal selection, education on behavior change techniques while supporting for initial and sustained efforts to develop a brain healthy lifestyle. Decision aids that include psychoeducation and explicit support for prevention decisions are preferred by patients and associated with better outcome[46]. Matching a person's interests to the information actually presented to them is also associated with improved outcomes[47], while information tailored to individuals' characteristics, needs, and interests has been shown to have a positive effect on health behavior[48].Key behavior change components of the model are the following: Psychoeducation. Information is key in supporting health-related behavior change[49]. In the model's implementation, we provide information on the Cogstim model, evidence-based intervention choice, and key risk and protective factors for cognitive decline and dementia such as diet, exercise, sleep, and mental activity.__________________________________ Insert Table 4 about here __________________________________ Goal selection and older adults' preference. In his or her role as a consultant, the clinician can provide older persons with expert guidance on the potential utility of various lifestyle changes while taking their individual circumstances and Cogstim: Practical Model, Page 11

Problem solving. In addition to goal setting and self-monitoring, a key part of the SDM is recognizing and addressing barriers to behavior change. Record keeping provides the basis for discussion with clinicians on progress toward goals and the ability to address barriers to goal attainment. Support for initial and sustained change. Success in preventing or delaying cognitive decline and dementia depends not only on initial but sustained behavior change. A key factor in sustained lifestyle changes is the integration of lifestyle with personal goals, as suggested by self-determination theory [52]. Implementing the model Implementation of the model presumes that the older adult's underlying health status has been assessed for common health conditions such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, diabetes, or thyroid dysfunction and appropriate treatments have been provided. The model provides useful starting points for discussion of brain health. Organization of preventive mechanisms into three groups allows older adults to Cogstim: Practical Model, Page 12 consider choices based on what may be the most important aspect of brain health for them to target. Integrating activities with evidence-based criteria such as consistency of evidence and effect size provides a guide for prioritizing behavior change goals. Initial suggestions to older adults for goals in developing a brain healthy lifestyle should thus be based on research support for their effectiveness and the number of preventive mechanisms they target. Aerobic exercise is linked to brain stimulation and reduced inflammation, and given the clearly positive effects of exercise on brain health as well as many other aspects of older adults' well-being, exercise may be an excellent initial goal if an older adult wants to develop a more brain healthy lifestyle. For those already engaging in regular exercise, the next logical targets might be either diet (again, depending on their status), meditation, or computer-based cognitive training. After achieving an initial goal, the older person can then maintain change while selecting another target.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: Due to the nature of Forum articles, the authors did not use any original data or follow any specific analysis techniques, and pre-registration was not required.
